Accordion component

An accordion component is a collection of expandable panels associated with a common outer container. Panels consist of a header and an associated content region or panel. The primary use of an Accordion is to present multiple sections of content on a single page without scrolling [...]

Contents

  • Keyboard interaction
  • Demo: accordion control using lrtiste
    • Supported keyboard interactions
  • Method: using a set of collapsing sections
  • Give lrtiste control

Keyboard interactions

The recommended keyboard interaction is quite complex and you should probably refer to it for a better understanding. The idea is to be able to navigate through the content while keeping the TAB queue short and giving the ability to switch from one item to the other using arrows instead.

Demo: accordion control using lrtiste

Here is an example of the accordion group widget enhanced by lrtiste. It has keyboard support and aria-states management as well.

Header one

Content of section 1 with a focusable element

Header two

Content of section 2 with a focusable element

Header three

Content of section 3 with a focusable element

Header four

Content of section 4 with a focusable element

Supported keyboard interactions

Here arte the supported keyboard interactions

When focus is on the header of an accordion

  • TAB key will select the next open accordion if any and put focus on the next focusable element within this accordion. If none is open, focus will leave the accordion group and go on the next focusable element in the page
  • left arrow and up arrow will select previous accordion and put focus on previous accordion header
  • right arrow and down arrow will select next accordion and put focus on next accordion header

When focus is on any focusable element within an accordion

  • TAB key will select the next open accordion if any and put focus on the next focusable element within this accordion. If none is open, focus will leave the accordion group and go on the next focusable element in the page
  • SHIFT + TAB will put focus on the accordion header

Method: using a set of collapsing sections

You could start by making your different sections expandable as shown in the expandable sections tutorial and let lrtiste take controls

Give lrtiste control

The markup must be made of a container with the role tablist. It is recommended to add the multiselect attribute to make sure the assistive technologies understand they are dealing with an accordion rather than regular tabs (although it will be added by lrtiste if Javascript is available).

Within the container, you should use regular section markup and add the relevant roles as lrtiste will use your semantic to find out which elements are part of your accordion group. By doing so, you'll make sure you content is accessible even without Javascript enabled.

  • Markup
  • Style
  • Script

index.html


<div id="accordions-sample" role="tablist">
  <h4 id="tab1" tabindex="0" role="tab" aria-controls="tabpanel1"><span class="adorner" aria-hidden="true"></span>Header one</h4>
  <p id="tabpanel1" aria-labelledby="tab1" role="tabpanel">Content of section 1 with a <a href="#foo">focusable element</a></p>
  <h4 id="tab2" role="tab" aria-controls="tabpanel2"><span class="adorner" aria-hidden="true"></span>Header two</h4>
  <p id="tabpanel2" aria-labelledby="tab2" role="tabpanel">Content of section 2 with a <a href="#foo">focusable element</a></p>
  <h4 id="tab3" role="tab" aria-controls="tabpanel3"><span class="adorner" aria-hidden="true"></span>Header three</h4>
  <p id="tabpanel3" aria-labelledby="tab3" role="tabpanel">Content of section 3 with a <a href="#foo">focusable element</a></p>
  <h4 id="tab4" role="tab" aria-controls="tabpanel4"><span class="adorner" aria-hidden="true"></span>Header four</h4>
  <p id="tabpanel4" aria-labelledby="tab4" role="tabpanel">Content of section 4 with a <a href="#foo">focusable element</a></p>
</div>

theme.css

#accordions-sample {
    padding: 1rem;
}

#accordions-sample > * {
    margin: 0;
}

#accordions-sample [role=tabpanel] {
    background: #e8e8e8;
    padding: 1rem;
}

/* simple arrow adorners */
#accordions-sample .adorner {
    padding: 0.5rem;
}

#accordions-sample .adorner:after {
    content: '\25b7\0020';
}

#accordions-sample [role=tab] {
    padding: 0.5rem;
    border: 1px solid #4b4b4b;
}

#accordions-sample [role=tab][aria-expanded=true] > .adorner:after {
    content: '\25bd\0020';
}

/*end adorner */

#accordions-sample [role=tabpanel][aria-hidden=true] {
    display: none;
}

#accordions-sample [role=tabpanel][aria-hidden=false] {
    animation-name: tabpanel-in;
    animation-duration: 0.3s;
    animation-timing-function: ease-out;
}

#accordions-sample [role=tab][aria-selected=true] {
    background: lightsalmon;
    color: white;
}

/*react to both keyboard and mouse focus*/
#accordions-sample [role=tab]:focus,
#accordions-sample [role=tab]:hover {
    background: salmon;
    outline: 0;
    color: white;
    box-shadow: 0 0 5px 0 black;
    transform: scale(1.02, 1.02);
    transition: all 0.3s;
}

@keyframes tabpanel-in {
    0% {
        transform: scaleY(0);
        transform-origin: top;
        opacity: 0;
    }
    100% {
        transform-origin: top;
        transform: scaleY(1);
        opacity: 1;
    }
}

we use the #accordions-sample to scope the style to our component. In practice you would use a more generic selector

index.js

import {accordion} from '../../../../components/accordions';

const accordionFactory = accordion();
accordionFactory({el:document.getElementById('accordions-sample')});

Just pass the dom element to the factory and lrtiste will do the rest: keyboar interaction and aria-states management.
